author: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
title: Pakistan Election Surprise: Imran Khan’s Party Puts Up a Fight
description: The military had cracked down on the party of the former prime minister in favor of another former leader, Nawaz Sharif. But Mr. Sharif’s party was lagging as results trickled in.
content: Pakistani voters on Friday were anxiously awaiting the final results of a national election that has stunned many in the country by denying Pakistan’s powerful military a widely expected landslide victory for its preferred party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Sleep Deprivation Can Affect Memory
description: Even just one night of less than six hours of rest can impair short-term memory.
content: We’re all familiar with the feeling of running on fumes after a night of little to no sleep. Sleep deprivation doesn’t just feel terrible, though: It also can hamper your ability to form and recall memories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Erica L. Green
title: In Private Remarks to Arab Americans, Biden Aide Expresses Regrets on Gaza
description: In a closed-door meeting, the aide offered some of the administration’s clearest notes of contrition for its response to the Gaza war, a sign of rising Democratic pressure on President Biden.
content: In a closed-door meeting with Arab American leaders in Michigan this week, one of President Biden’s top foreign policy aides acknowledged mistakes in the administration’s response to the war in Gaza, saying he did not have “any confidence” that Israel’s government was willing to take “meaningful steps” toward Palestinian statehood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Pistachio Cheesecake, 2 Ways: Super Simple and Simply Showstopping
description: The slightly sweet nut shines in these two smart recipes from Melissa Clark.
content: Winsome and delicate with an intense perfume, pistachio is having a moment, adding its pale green charm to cream puffs and croissants, lattes and cocktails. But how, I wondered, would it fare in a cheesecake, that timeless queen of rich and plush desserts? To find out, I made pistachio cheesecakes the subject of the latest episode of my YouTube show, “Shortcut vs. Showstopper,” in which, true to the title, I come up with two iterations of one recipe: a simple version that anyone could make, and a more complex, special version guaranteed to make heads spin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: A Compact, Eco-Friendly House and Three (Not-So-Little) Pigs
description: The 1,200-square-foot home in coastal Maine uses a fraction of the energy required to heat the average house, and the pigs handle most of the yardwork.
content: This is the story of two athletic people who formed an attachment while cycling and made a home together near the coast of Maine. They built a small, energy-efficient house northwest of Camden that is comfortable throughout the year: in frigid season, sopping season, insect season. It’s got it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
title: Welcome to Japan, Taylor Swift Fans. Please Remain Seated as You Cheer.
description: Some Japanese spectators are grumbling that foreign concertgoers visiting Tokyo don’t share their rather restrained local approach to taking in a show.
content: Taylor mania has landed in Tokyo. But the enthusiasm of some of the Swifties arriving with her has clashed with local sensibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Erica L. Green and Katie Glueck
title: White House Calls Special Counsel Report on Biden Politically Motivated
description: The White House and some Democrats tried to discredit a document that characterized the president as elderly and forgetful.
content: White House officials on Friday called the special counsel’s report into President Biden’s handling of classified material politically motivated, escalating their attempts to discredit a document that characterized the president as elderly and forgetful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Sounds of Melodrama
description: Christina Iverson offers solvers a challenging Friday puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Who Will Replace Ronna McDaniel as Leader of the R.N.C.?
description: Two of the Republicans who battled for co-chairman last year appear poised for Round 2, but this time party leadership is at stake and the former president may hold more sway.
content: The disclosure that Ronna McDaniel is planning to step down this month as the leader of the Republican National Committee has set off a new round of jockeying between two of the same men who battled for the co-chairman post last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Stories Do You Want to Read About Asian American Communities?
description: We want input from readers to help shape our coverage so we can more comprehensively cover the fastest-growing category in America.
content: I’m Amy Qin, a reporter for The New York Times. After more than a decade in Asia, where I lived in Beijing and Taipei and mostly wrote about China and Taiwan, I moved back to the United States in 2022 to write about Asian American communities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Will the Super Bowl Affect Fans’ Political Views? Bet on It.
description: A psychologist at Tulane University offers insights into just how powerfully sporting events can get into our heads.
content: Damian R. Murray, a psychologist at Tulane University, studies how various social circumstances and life events affect people’s political views. For instance, he found recently, becoming a parent makes a person grow more socially conservative. On the eve of the Super Bowl, he sat down for an interview with The New York Times to discuss another recent study, which examined how the political perspectives of sports fans can be altered by their teams’ wins and losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: ‘New York New Jersey’ Got the World Cup Final. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: Officials are already preparing for the logistical challenge of hosting eight games of the immensely popular soccer tournament at MetLife Stadium.
content: The governor of New Jersey leaped from his chair and raised his hands high above his head as if he had just scored the winning goal in a World Cup final. In a way, he had.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: It Started as Winter Break. It Ended With a Doomed Moon Mission.
description: Carnegie Mellon University students built Iris, a tiny lunar rover. When the spacecraft carrying it to the moon malfunctioned, they turned their vacation house into mission control.
content: A gaggle of students from Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh traveled to Florida last month during their winter break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: Our Super Bowls, Ourselves
description: On the mass cultural events that unite us — and where we’d be without them.
content: What do Lady Diana’s wedding, the “Survivor” first-season finale and Prince’s 2007 Super Bowl halftime show have in common? They were huge cultural moments that brought millions of Americans together. In an era of streaming, social media bubbles and sharp political divides, are unifying events like these becoming relics?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Old Hollywood Glamour at the Gap?
description: Unlikely, but with Zac Posen being named its creative director, you never know. Plus, fashion’s doll fixation, thrift shopping at H&M and pop-ups to pop by.
content: No sooner, it seems, had Zac Posen whipped up a series of ball gowns for a TV miniseries than he was named to top creative positions at brands better known for cargo pants and pajama sets. On Monday Mr. Posen, 43, whose namesake brand ceased operations in 2019, was announced as the new creative director of Gap Inc. and the new chief creative officer of Old Navy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: President Biden was not charged in connection with his handling of documents. Here’s the latest.
description: Just hours after a special counsel examining his handling of sensitive information put a spotlight on his age and memory, President Biden is set to speak.
content: Just hours after a special counsel examining his handling of sensitive information put a spotlight on his age and memory, President Biden is set to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include a decades-spanning Chinese drama, a thriller about a teenage immigrant in Canada, an absurdist French crime comedy and more.
content: The scenes that open this ravishing drama by Wang Xiaoshuai feel like pieces of a cryptic puzzle, gesturing evocatively at a whole that remains out of view. A pair of boys play beside a lake, a death is seen from a distance, and years later, in some other place, a grieving couple struggle to raise a wayward son. Slowly, these fragments swirl together into a decades-spanning epic about two couples in China, brought together in the 1980s by their factory jobs and then torn apart by a series of losses, including those inflicted by the country’s one-child policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Trump Wades Into Montana’s Crucial Senate Race, Backing Establishment Pick
description: Donald J. Trump endorsed Tim Sheehy hours after one of Mr. Trump’s longtime allies entered the race. Some party leaders had hoped to avoid a contested primary.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Tim Sheehy for the Republican Senate nomination in Montana on Friday, putting his powerful imprimatur on the primary race hours after one of his longtime allies, Representative Matt Rosendale, joined the contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wei Tchou
title: The Nostalgic Appeal of Mung Bean Desserts
description: Asian American pastry chefs are making something new of the humble legume.
content: At the Malaysian pastry shop Kuih Cafe in downtown Manhattan, the baker Veronica Gan, who’s in her mid-50s, sells ang ku kueh, a piece of pliant, toothsome ruby red mochi molded in the shape of a tortoiseshell. Mochi itself has little flavor — its pleasures are textural — but bite into the confection and you find that it’s stuffed with sweet mung bean paste. Starchy, subtly nutty and slightly sweet, it lingers on the tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Kevin Draper
title: Super Bowl Broadcast Is a Crossroads for CBS Sports
description: The storied network is facing a wave of change, including new leadership, the possible sale of its parent company and the continued challenge of streaming.
content: On the one hand, Sunday will be a joyous occasion for CBS Sports. The sports division will broadcast its 22nd Super Bowl, the most of any network. The game is guaranteed to be the most-watched event in television this year, and it will generate hundreds of millions in advertising revenue and provide a huge promotional platform for CBS and its parent company, Paramount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Rowbottom
title: Are We All Technosexuals Now?
description: Our erotic and romantic lives have become ever more tangled with machines.
content: On a rainy afternoon in January, I’m sitting at my computer in an empty house. The holidays are over; the parties, too. It’s a lonely time of year, but, browsing the internet, I stumble on a site called Candy.ai that promises to help. “Your dream companion awaits,” reads the homepage. “Create your A.I. girlfriend, shape her look, personality, and bring her to life in one click.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Grading Biden’s Signature Law
description: The climate-focused Inflation Reduction Act is popular with businesses. But its cost is expected to double over the next decade, and its outlook is uncertain.
content: In the past 24 hours, President Biden has taken questions (and heat) on his age, memory and mental fitness. But the one economic issue that is most likely to generate scrutiny from the business community and beyond over the next several months is the biggest bill he has passed, the Inflation Reduction Act, which he hailed at his news conference last night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: Tracy Chapman makes a triumphant return. Also, the $1.50 shoes that even Gucci wants to copy, and at 116, she is celebrated by an entire town.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reading Recommendations From Book Review Staffers
description: Here’s what they’ve enjoyed in 2024.
content: The early part of a year can mean new books to read, or it can mean catching up on older ones we haven’t gotten to yet. This week, Gilbert Cruz chats with the Book Review’s Sarah Lyall and Sadie Stein about titles from both categories that have held their interest lately, including a 2022 biography of John Donne, a book about female artists who nurtured an interest in the supernatural, and the history of a Jim Crow-era mental asylum, along with a gripping new novel by Janice Hallett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Katie Thomas
title: Staggering Rise in Catheter Bills Suggests Medicare Scam
description: Seven medical supply companies made suspicious claims involving thousands of Medicare beneficiaries, an advocacy group found.
content: Linda Hennis was checking her Medicare statement in January when she noticed something strange: It said a company she had never heard of had been paid about $12,000 for sending her 2,000 urinary catheters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Popova
title: A Long-Forgotten TV Script by Rachel Carson Is Now a Picture Book
description: In “Something About the Sky,” the National Book Award-winning marine biologist brings her signature sense of wonder to the science of clouds.
content: A cloud is a spell against indifference, an emblem of the water cycle that makes this planet a living world capable of trees and tenderness, a great cosmic gasp at the improbability that such a world exists, that across the cold expanse of space-time, strewn with billions upon billions of other star systems, there is nothing like it as far as we yet know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: As Her Husband Faces Tumult, Jill Biden Is a Protective Force
description: The first lady has said that the presidency is “a lot” for President Biden, but that neither she nor her husband wants Donald J. Trump to return to office.
content: The special counsel report on President Biden’s handling of classified information has led to questions about the president’s fitness to run for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Let’s Go Ice Skating. In the Backyard.
description: People around the country are building private rinks — some with as little as a garden hose and patience.
content: Josh Allen had always wanted to try ice skating. “It looked like something fun to do that was good exercise,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Rejects Putin’s Latest Call for Ukraine Negotiations
description: Skepticism remains high about the Russian leader’s intentions after he told Tucker Carlson that the war in Ukraine could be settled with a peace deal.
content: The Biden administration dismissed on Friday a call by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, showing no sign that flagging political support for American military aid to Kyiv had made President Biden more inclined to make concessions to Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: D.N.C. Files Federal Election Complaint Against Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
description: Democrats accused Mr. Kennedy of illegally coordinating with a super PAC to get him onto the ballot in several states that could be critical to President Biden.
content: In a federal election complaint filed on Friday, the Democratic National Committee accused Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and a super PAC backing his independent presidential bid of illegally coordinating on a $15 million petition drive intended to qualify him for the ballot in several states that could be crucial to President Biden’s re-election prospects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Richard Gambino, 84, Dies; Fought Discrimination Against Italian Americans
description: He directed the Italian American studies program at Queens College — the first of its type in American academia — and wrote about his ethnic group in “Blood of My Blood.”
content: Richard Gambino, the chairman of the first academic Italian American studies program in the United States and a leading critic of those who reflexively viewed Italian Americans as Mafiosi and mocked them with ethnic stereotypes in popular culture, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Southampton, N.Y. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Brooke Ellison, Prominent Disability Rights Advocate, Is Dead at 45
description: One of the first quadriplegic Harvard graduates, she became an author, professor and powerful voice for disabled people.
content: Brooke Ellison, who after being paralyzed from the neck down by a childhood car accident went on to graduate from Harvard and became a professor and devoted disability rights advocate, died on Sunday in Stony Brook, N.Y. She was 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Employers Can Now Enroll Workers in Some Emergency Savings Accounts
description: But many companies are spurning the “clunky” legal requirements for accounts linked to retirement plans. Instead, some have stand-alone rainy day offerings.
content: Starting this year, a federal law allows employers to enroll workers in emergency savings accounts that are linked to their retirement accounts. But some companies, put off by the law’s complex rules, have begun offering rainy day benefits outside workplace retirement plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: In Sickness and … Well, Mostly Sickness
description: It took a couple of fleeting viruses for Victoria Voos and Corey Buresch to “hard launch,” she said, into becoming a very committed couple.
content: Getting sick is not usually something for which people are grateful. But Victoria Virginia Voos and Corey Alexander Buresch certainly are. “It seemed like illness, one way or another, kept our relationship progressing to the next level,” Ms. Voos said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Willy Chavarria: Designer, Activist and Now, Auteur
description: In his first foray into filmmaking, Willy Chavarria once more tests the boundaries of representation, gender and taste.
content: “Hideous,” said Willy Chavarria, talking about the fashion business, celebrity entitlement, late-stage capitalism, his current state of mind. It was a Thursday morning at a workroom in the Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn, and the designer was putting last-minute touches on his fall 2024 collection of the men’s wear that, in recent years, has been taken up by a number of people who do not identify as men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Bullfighting in the Arena and Battling Outside of It
description: James Wagner, who covers Latin America for The New York Times, recently reported on a clash over a centuries-old tradition in Mexico City.
content: In November, a colleague at The New York Times invited me to an exhibition tennis match between Carlos Alcaraz and Tommy Paul at a historic venue: La Plaza México, the largest bullfighting arena in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: When the Food Is Lovingly Prepared by the Actors (and the Chef)
description: “The Taste of Things” didn’t use cooking doubles, but a pro offscreen helped guide the stars. Getting the meals right was everything to the director Tran Anh Hung.
content: Viewers may emerge from “The Taste of Things” desperate to find a restaurant that serves a good vol-au-vent, a turbot in hollandaise sauce or the meringue-coated ice cream confection known as baked alaska. But while the film, set in France at the end of the 19th century, features period-appropriate cuisine designed by the celebrated chef Pierre Gagnaire, the secret to what makes it so enticing isn’t the menu. It’s the gestures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: She Promoted His Music From the Start. Romance Waited.
description: Carissa Bauman volunteered to hand out fliers for one of Dylan Jakobsen’s music gigs. She later became his best friend and manager.
content: Carissa Anne Bauman had no idea who Dylan Taylor Jakobsen was when he handed her a flier on Dec. 26, 2010, outside El Corazon, a downtown Seattle music club, while she and a friend waited in line to see Scene Aesthetic, a local acoustic rock band.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: America Between Jesus and Faust
description: Should we want a new American genesis?
content: In my Saturday column I dabbled in a peculiar kind of optimism about the American future, arguing that if we can avoid various forms of self-destruction over the next decade or two, we might find ourselves in a better position than almost any peer or rival — as an aging world’s last bastion of dynamism and growth, possibly centered around the New America taking shape in the Sun Belt cities and the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Taylor Swift Gives Kansas City Its Own Love Story
description: It’s a new era for lovers of the defending Super Bowl champions in their home city. No, they won’t calm down.
content: Prayer candles adorned with the faces of Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift gaze out from shop windows. Chiefs flags flutter on car windows zipping down highways. Red clothing appears to be mandatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski
title: Putin to U.S.: Let’s Make a Deal on Ukraine (on My Terms)
description: The Russian leader clearly believes he can now negotiate from strength, but the message in the Tucker Carlson interview was muddled, critics say.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia kept returning to one message over and over in his meandering, two-hour interview with the former Fox News host Tucker Carlson: Russia wants to negotiate a peace deal in Ukraine, albeit on the Kremlin’s terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Tucker Carlson Regains the Bullhorn, at Least Temporarily
description: Mr. Carlson’s interview with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia put him back on center stage for the first time since his Fox News show was canceled.
content: Last spring, it seemed Tucker Carlson might have reached the end of his fiery path through American media and politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Sad Songs Do You Listen to When You’re Feeling Down?
description: Tell us about a time when music has helped you through heartbreak, grief or loneliness.
content: Do you ever turn to music in times of grief or heartache? What song or songs do you put on when you want to get into your feelings? How have they helped you through difficult moments?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Eric Schmitt
title: Ukraine Has a New Military Commander but the Problems Haven’t Changed
description: As Gen. Oleksandr Syrsky assumes his role, he must reckon with a grim calculus: When does the cost of defending ground outweigh any benefit gained by inflicting pain on the enemy?
content: Russian forces are razing the already battered city of Avdiivka in eastern Ukraine to the ground and sending waves of assault units to overwhelm outgunned Ukrainian troops. After months of brutal fighting, the Russian military is threatening to cut off a vital supply line to the city, which could render further defense impossible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How the N.F.L. Became a Juggernaut of Entertainment
description: The game of football has been engineered over decades to promote spectacular strategy.
content: The National Football League, founded in 1920, was an unpopular pipsqueak 90 or so years ago. The low-paid players barely practiced because they couldn’t take time away from their weekday jobs. The college player who went first in the 1936 draft, a Heisman Trophy winner, decided to become a foam rubber salesman instead of turning pro. Strategy was rudimentary, partly because passing the ball was restricted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Austerlitz
title: 40 Years Ago, This Ad Changed the Super Bowl Forever
description: An oral history of Apple’s groundbreaking “1984” spot, which helped to establish the Super Bowl as TV’s biggest commercial showcase.
content: Four decades ago, the Super Bowl became the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Friday Briefing
description: A special counsel clears Biden.
content: Even though President Biden retained classified material after leaving the vice presidency in 2017, “no criminal charges are warranted,” the special counsel investigating the issue wrote in a report released yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: John Bruton Dies at 76; Negotiated for Peace as Irish Prime Minister
description: He made strides to end the sectarian violence that plagued Northern Ireland through the 1990s by collaborating with both Britain and the Irish Republican Army.
content: John Bruton, a former Irish prime minister who led an alliance known as the Rainbow Coalition and played a central role with Britain in an effort to secure peace in Northern Ireland after decades of strife, died on Tuesday in Dublin. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Demolition of Muslim Properties Sets Off Deadly Violence in India
description: When officials arrived to raze a mosque and seminary ruled to be illegally located on public property, they encountered hundreds of protesters.
content: The demolition of a mosque and a Muslim seminary has led to deadly clashes and an internet shutdown in northern India. The flare-up, in the hill state of Uttarakhand, is the latest bout of sectarian tensions as Muslim sites have become a broader target of the Hindu right wing after the opening of a major temple last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucie Young
title: See the Beatles’ First Tour Through Paul McCartney’s Lens
description: Sixty years after the Beatles appeared live on “Ed Sullivan,” McCartney reflects on his photos capturing those halcyon days. The Brooklyn Museum will exhibit them, and some will be for sale later.
content: They are now a collector’s trove — Paul McCartney’s own photos, shot 60 years ago, when the Beatles took Europe and America by storm: images of screaming fans (one carrying a live monkey); a girl in a yellow bikini; airport workers playing air guitar, and unguarded moments grabbed from trains, planes and automobiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James R. Oestreich
title: Seiji Ozawa, a Captivating, Transformative Conductor, Dies at 88
description: He led the Boston Symphony Orchestra for 29 years, toured widely and helped dispel prejudices about East Asian classical musicians.
content: Seiji Ozawa, the high-spirited Japanese conductor who took the Western classical music world by storm in the 1960s and ’70s and then led the Boston Symphony Orchestra for almost 30 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Tokyo. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Barron
title: How Two Irish Businessmen Almost Took Nigeria for $11 Billion
description: A mundane contractual provision met with rampant corruption — revealing a serious vulnerability in one of the backbones of international commerce.
content: Like a lot of explosive financial scandals, the story of Michael Quinn and Brendan Cahill could fairly be described as a simple proposition that spun completely out of control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Three Big Legal Questions
description: A guide to the Supreme Court arguments on Donald Trump and the ballot.
content: There are still court cases that could upend this year’s presidential election, but the one involving Donald Trump’s eligibility to be on the ballot doesn’t seem likely to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Adam Liptak, Rob Szypko, Lynsea Garrison, Mary Wilson, Alex Young, Paige Cowett, Brendan Klinkenberg, Marion Lozano, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: Kick Trump Off the Ballot? Even Liberal Justices Are Skeptical.
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments about whether Donald Trump can be ruled ineligible to run in Colorado’s presidential primaries.
content: In December, the Colorado Supreme Court issued a bombshell ruling that said Donald Trump was ineligible to be on the state’s ballot for the Republican presidential primary, saying he was disqualified under the 14th Amendment of the Constitution because he had engaged in insurrection on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero and Dolly Faibyshev
title: America Ferrera, Katie Holmes, and Carey Mulligan Turn Out for Chanel
description: The brand hosted a celebrity-fueled bash for its U.S. foray into high-end jewelry.
content: On Wednesday night, a throng of actors, cycling through a swirl of events — awards season, New York Fashion Week and the Super Bowl — assembled in Midtown Manhattan, wearing Chanel, dressed by Chanel and for Chanel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Is the Senate Becoming the House?
description: The failure of border legislation exposed serious fault lines among Senate Republicans that rivaled the G.O.P. discord across the Rotunda.
content: In 2008, as the nation faced a catastrophic financial crisis, the House did what it sometimes does — veered off the rails. In a raucous and startling floor vote, lawmakers defeated a $700 billion bank bailout, sending the markets plummeting as the economy teetered. It was the steadier Senate that had to step in and take over, find a way to approve the legislation and show the House how it was done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: The Friar Who Became the Vatican’s Go-To Guy on A.I.
description: Paolo Benanti advises the Roman Catholic Church and the Italian government on the tricky questions, moral and otherwise, raised by the rapidly advancing technology.
content: Before dawn, Paolo Benanti climbed to the bell tower of his 16th-century monastery, admired the sunrise over the ruins of the Roman forum and reflected on a world in flux.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Seek to Protect Witnesses in Trump Classified Documents Case
description: The move to shield the identities of several witnesses suggested a mounting sense of frustration with Judge Aileen M. Cannon, who is overseeing the case.
content: Prosecutors have asked a federal judge to protect the identities of several witnesses involved in the criminal case accusing former President Donald J. Trump of illegally retaining classified documents, saying that if their names were revealed before trial they could be exposed to “intolerable and needless risks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Does a President’s Age Matter? Tell Us.
description: President Biden, at 81, is the oldest president in the nation’s history and former President Donald J. Trump is not far behind, at 77.
content: A special counsel’s report referring to President Biden as a “well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory” and the president’s performance at a news conference on Thursday night has once again made his age a center of political debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Journal Retracts Studies Cited in Federal Court Ruling Against Abortion Pill
description: The journal found that the studies, which had suggested that medication abortion is unsafe, included incorrect factual assumptions and misleading presentation of the data.
content: An academic journal publisher this week retracted two studies that were cited by a federal judge in Texas last year when he ruled that the abortion pill mifepristone should be taken off the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer
title: Israeli Settlers Left Gaza in 2005. They Now See a Chance to Return.
description: The United States and many other nations are pushing Israel to hand Gaza back to Palestinian leadership. But within Israel, a powerful lobby is trying to rally support for Jewish settlements there.
content: A group of Israelis hoping to live in Gaza at the war’s end has already published maps imagining Jewish-majority towns dotting the territory. Far-right Israeli lawmakers have drafted plans to make such settlements legal. And Israel’s national security minister has called for Arab residents to leave Gaza so that Jews can populate the coastal strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Glenn Thrush and Peter Baker
title: ‘My Memory Is Fine,’ a Defiant Biden Declares After Special Counsel Report
description: The special counsel opted not to pursue charges against the president but raised questions about his mental acuity, which the White House disputes.
content: President Biden angrily hit back against a special counsel’s report on his handling of classified documents on Thursday, denying that he willfully retained papers that he was not entitled to keep and insisting that “my memory is fine” despite questions raised by the prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lance Larson, Who Lost a Disputed Olympic Swim Race, Dies at 83
description: He had the fastest time in the 100-meter freestyle final. But after a corps of judges couldn’t choose a winner, the chief judge declared one. It wasn’t Larson.
content: Lance Larson, a champion Southern California swimmer whose apparent victory in the 100-meter freestyle race at the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome was snatched away within minutes by the chief judge, died on Jan. 19 in Orange, Calif. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Two People Sitting
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck
title: Eight Words and a Verbal Slip Put Biden’s Age Back at the Center of 2024
description: A special counsel’s stinging report and an uneven White House appearance captured Democrats’ fears about President Biden and fueled Republicans as they try to cast him as weak.
content: When President Biden appeared at a last-minute news conference on Thursday night, he hoped to assure the country of his mental acuity hours after a special counsel’s report had devastatingly referred to him as a “well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Mother-in-Law Hasn’t Saved for Retirement. Are We On the Hook?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the financial support owed to an aging in-law.
content: My mother-in-law is in her 50s and has worked as a horse trainer her whole life. She doesn’t own property and instead rents a house at the barn where she trains. She has no assets or retirement plan and is getting to the point where doing the job is becoming more difficult for her physically. My husband has tried to talk to her about her fiscal future, and she shuts these conversations down; she likes to talk about “someday” winning the lottery and buying her own place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: At First, He Was in His Head, but Her ‘Gut Instinct’ Prevailed
description: Yuna Yang and Christopher Seck became good friends before she proposed becoming something more. He took three months to consider.
content: The soccer World Cup final in December 2022 ended with a nail-biting win for Argentina. For Yuna Yang and Christopher Mun-Yin Seck, the day was exciting for other reasons, too: After watching the match at a private club, the two spent hours together in New York, where they both live, and by the end of the day, realized that their friendship had romantic potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: David Kahn, Leading Historian of Codes and Code Breaking, Dies at 93
description: His 1967 book, “The Codebreakers,” introduced the world to cryptology and inspired the emergence of private-sector encrypted communication.
content: David Kahn, whose 1967 book, “The Codebreakers,” established him as the world’s pre-eminent authority on cryptology — the science of making and breaking secret codes — died on Jan. 24 in the Bronx. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Why Don’t We Hang Out Anymore?
description: Adults need to relax and do nothing together, just like kids do.
content: For the past few weeks, I’ve been running an experiment: inviting friends to simply hang out and do nothing, or close to nothing. I’ve asked them to drop by for a cup of tea. I’ve volunteered to join them as they walk their dogs. When I found out that my local grocery store opened at 7 a.m., I asked a fellow early riser if she wanted to get her shopping done early with me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Jesus Jiménez
title: Plane Crashes on Florida Highway, Killing 2, Authorities Say
description: The plane, a Bombardier Challenger 600 series jet, was carrying five people when it crashed on Interstate 75 near Naples, Fla., the authorities said.
content: A small plane carrying five people crashed on Interstate 75 near Naples, Fla., on Friday afternoon, exploding in flames and killing two people, according to officials. They said that three of those onboard were able to get out of the plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers Tackles the Supreme Court’s Trump Hearing
description: Meyers said Trump lacked “any sense of irony or self-awareness” when “he claimed it would be an attack on democracy to remove him from the ballot for attacking democracy.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Reversing Course, Guinness Gives a Frenchman’s Eiffel Tower the Record
description: Weeks after disqualifying a 24-foot tower made of matchsticks, Guinness World Records apologized and said it had been too “heavy handed.”
content: Richard Plaud toiled over eight years to construct a nearly 24-foot model of the Eiffel Tower. Each of the 706,900 matchsticks he glued together brought the Frenchman one step closer toward his dream: achieving a world record for building the tallest matchstick sculpture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greta Rybus
title: Dipping Into the World’s Most Stunning Hot Springs
description: From onsens in Japan to high-altitude pools in Bolivia, the photographer Greta Rybus shares highlights from her search for thermal waters.
content: Some hot springs look like palaces, others like holes in the ground. Some feel like parties, others like prayers. There are hot baths within cities, on remote islands, in the desert, inside thick forests. Thermal water can be green, orange, blue, yellow or turquoise. It can be milky and opaque, silty with sediment or as clear as a municipal pool. Sometimes it’s barely lukewarm; other times it’s so hot it hurts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden sharpens criticism of Israel, calling its Gaza response ‘over the top.’
description: “There are a lot of innocent people who are in trouble and dying,” the president said in a session with reporters. “And it’s got to stop.”
content: President Biden sharply escalated his criticism of Israel’s approach to the war against Hamas on Thursday, calling military operations in Gaza “over the top” and saying that the suffering of innocent people has “got to stop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Tina Antolini, Dan Powell, Daniel Ramirez and Jon Pareles
title: New Music for Your Weekend
description: Comebacks, heartbreaks and a tribute to a jazz legend.
content: Jon Pareles, The Times’s chief pop music critic, picks his favorite new tracks to listen to this weekend:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart’s puzzle might remind you that all you need is love (love, love).
content: ACROSTIC — We’re a few days from commemorating St. Valentine and I genuinely thought that today’s passage was chosen to correspond to that occasion. Maybe it was all the romantic songs that ran through my mind as I solved, like “Love Me Do,” “I Want to Hold Your Hand,” “If I Fell” and “All My Loving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: In a Victory for Poland Spring, Maine Rejects New Groundwater Limits
description: The bottled-water company last year tried to kill legislation aimed at protecting aquifers at a time when many are at risk nationally.
content: Maine’s Legislature voted down a bill that would have limited large-scale pumping of groundwater in the state. Poland Spring, the bottled-water giant, had lobbied aggressively against the measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Whatever Happens at the Super Bowl, She’s Already Won
description: Taylor Swift helped Kristin Juszczyk turn the stadium tunnel into the new fashion runway, and Sunday’s game will be the ultimate show.
content: Whichever team takes home the Vince Lombardi Trophy in Super Bowl LVIII, the San Francisco 49ers or the Kansas City Chiefs, there is already one indubitable winner. Not Taylor Swift, whose interest in football has attracted almost as many conspiracy theorists as fans, or even the N.F.L. itself, which is trying to figure out how to hang onto its sudden influx of Taylor-related female fans, but rather another player’s significant other: Kristin Juszczyk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Tucker Carlson Urges Putin to Release American Journalist
description: The Russian president was noncommittal after Mr. Carlson asked about Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter who has been held in a Moscow prison for nearly a year.
content: In an interview released on Thursday, Tucker Carlson urged President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to release an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who has been held in a notorious Moscow prison for nearly a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Can You Optimize an Orgasm?
description: An array of smart sex toys cater to those who want to take a data-driven approach to their pleasure.
content: After Melissa, a 35-year-old event planner living in Chicago, masturbates, she sometimes studies a chart that resembles the output of a heart rate monitor or that of a seismograph capturing an earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Can America Survive a Party of Saboteurs?
description: Republican cynicism seems to have no bottom.
content: Almost four years have passed since Congress approved and Donald Trump signed a huge relief bill designed to limit the financial hardship created by the Covid-19 pandemic. The CARES Act did its job. Although around 25 million Americans temporarily lost their jobs — with the job losses mainly caused by fear of infection rather than officially mandated shutdowns — there was far less monetary pain than you might have expected given the magnitude of the public health crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Ryan
title: H.I.V. Groups Warn of Privacy Risks in How C.D.C. Tracks Virus Samples
description: Since 2018, the agency has mandated tracking the genetic signatures of viruses collected from people with H.I.V., a practice known as molecular surveillance.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday revised its guidelines for tracking the genetic signatures of viruses collected from people newly diagnosed with H.I.V., a controversial practice used by state and local health departments to curb infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Chief Witness Against Gaetz Is Cooperating With House Ethics Investigation
description: A year after the Justice Department decided not to bring charges against Representative Matt Gaetz in a sex-trafficking investigation, the House Ethics Committee is moving forward with an inquiry into him.
content: A lawyer for the chief witness against Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida, said on Friday that the witness was cooperating with a House Ethics Committee investigation into whether Mr. Gaetz had sex with an underage girl while he was serving in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Paula Szuchman
title: Bluesky’s Big Bet, and Are Deals Dead in Silicon Valley?
description: Plus, more ancient scrolls deciphered using artificial intelligence, Google’s chatbot updates, and a fight between record labels and TikTok.
content: Bluesky, the Twitter spinoff, is now open for public sign-ups. Can its dreams of decentralization fix social media? We talk with the company’s chief executive, Jay Graber. Then, the New York Times reporter Erin Griffith on how Adobe’s failure to acquire Figma has spooked tech companies and upset Silicon Valley’s start-up pipeline. And finally, updates on ancient scrolls and artificial intelligence, Google’s chatbots, and the fight between record companies and TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren LeBlanc
title: Julianne Moore Channels Love and Loss in an Intimate Family Drama
description: The actor reads Michael Cunningham’s “Day,” a novel that visits a husband, wife and brother on the same day in April over three years.
content: Michael Cunningham’s “Day” is a gracefully restrained portrait of domestic yearning and claustrophobia, following a single family’s trajectory before, during and after the peak of the Covid-19 pandemic. Shifting among the perspectives of Isabel; her husband, Dan; and her brother, Robbie, who lives in the attic of the couple’s Brooklyn brownstone, the narrative takes place across three years, offering glimpses into their lives on the same April day in 2019, 2020 and 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden and Reid J. Epstein
title: Green Party Eligible for the Ballot in Wisconsin
description: In the critical battleground state where past winners have been decided by narrow margins, the Green Party’s presence could prove consequential.
content: Elections officials in Wisconsin voted that the Green Party is eligible to appear on presidential election ballots, a move that could affect the result in a critical battleground state where the winner has been decided by narrow margins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Hot Pot Is for Everyone
description: Pick your proteins, assemble your vegetables and simmer away.
content: Good morning. Hot pot’s on the docket for Saturday night: a big metal tureen of soup bubbling over a burner in the center of the dining table, into which we’ll float slices of beef, cubes of tofu, leafy greens, oyster mushrooms, rounds of sweet potato, rice cakes, cubes of daikon radish and lots and lots of dumplings to welcome the Lunar New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Biden’s Fiery Defiance, and a Skeptical Supreme Court
description: Plus, $7 million Super Bowl ads.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: 5 Takeaways From the Biden Classified Documents Investigation Report
description: The special counsel, Robert K. Hur, concluded that the evidence was insufficient to charge President Biden with a crime, but sharply criticized him.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Thursday released the report by Robert K. Hur, the special counsel Mr. Garland had assigned to investigate how classified documents ended up in an office formerly used by President Biden and in his home in Delaware. Here are some takeaways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: True-Crime Documentaries That Tell More About Us Than the Victims
description: Two new movies reflect the range of quality in the booming genre. They also raise questions about why we are drawn to such stories.
content: Remember the old “Arrested Development” axiom that “there’s always money in the banana stand”? For streamers, that banana stand is true crime, judging from the rate at which these movies are turned out. Many of the lurid tales of kidnapping, murder and stolen identities have been covered already in podcasts, but documentaries add tantalizing visual elements — photographs of the deceased, talking-head interviews, archival footage — that apparently keep fans coming back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Todd
title: 6 Self-Help Books That Therapists Read Themselves
description: Experts recommend these contemplative texts and workbooks to help shift your perspective.
content: Of the thousands of self-help books on the market, which ones are truly helpful? “It’s uncommon to find a self-help book that feels different,” said Vienna Pharaon, a marriage and family therapist in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Democrats Suffer a Comey Flashback
description: The special counsel’s report on President Biden instantly recalled how James Comey concluded his investigation of Hillary Clinton.
content: For veterans of Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign for president, yesterday brought back painful memories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Fisherman Convicted of Diverting a Michigan River by Hand
description: Andrew Blair Howard was found with a shovel at the site of a newly created channel at Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore, prosecutors said.
content: After the National Park Service stopped dredging the Platte River at Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore on Michigan’s lower peninsula, built-up sediment created a sandbar separating fishermen from a coho salmon run.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court and Trump’s Eligibility to Run
description: Readers discuss the debate over whether the 14th Amendment applies to the former president. Also: The spouse as caregiver.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Parents Are Highly Involved in Their Adult Children’s Lives, and Fine With It
description: New surveys show that today’s intensive parenting has benefits, not just risks, and most young adults seem happy with it, too.
content: American parenting has become more involved — requiring more time, money and mental energy — not just when children are young, but well into adulthood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Best-Loved Bridges in California
description: All sorts of spans can hold fascination, making geographic connections and, often, personal ones, too.
content: It’s Friday. Californians share their favorite bridges. Plus, Southern California’s oldest bookstore is looking for a buyer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Florian
title: When A.I. Bridged a Language Gap, They Fell in Love
description: He spoke English. She spoke Spanish. After the couple was set up on a blind date, an A.I.-powered lip-dubbing app helped them form a connection.
content: In June, LeRoy Romero drove four hours from his hometown, Peoria, Ariz., to an Applebee’s in Mexicali, Mexico, to meet Brenda Ochoa for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Age and Memory: A Pointed Report From the Special Counsel
description: Readers react to the report, which described the president as a “well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Kacey Musgraves’s Fingerpicked Epiphany, and 9 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Beth Gibbons, girl in red, Angélica Garcia and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu and Scott McIntyre
title: On the World’s Largest Cruise Ship, Thrills and Space to Chill
description: Our reporter joined thousands of passengers on the inaugural sailing of Royal Caribbean’s Icon of the Seas. Yes, the water rides were wild. But the most surprising thing she found? Some actual peace and quiet.
content: One man got down on his knees and kissed the rug emblazoned with the ship’s logo. Another lifted his wife and swung her around, ecstatic to be among the roughly 5,000 passengers to embark on the inaugural sailing of the world’s largest cruise ship, the Icon of the Seas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Salam Fayyad
description: The Feb. 9, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Salam Fayyad. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alec Wilkinson
title: Math Is the Answer to More Than One Question
description: I am only a mathematical tourist, but my experience has led me to believe that mathematics is rife with intimations of a divine presence.
content: I am surprised at this late stage, in my 70s, to be thinking about God. In my defense, I might say that I did not arrive at these thoughts by reflecting on my own inevitable end or from a religion or a Scripture or the example of a holy figure. I arrived by means of mathematics, specifically simple mathematics — algebra, geometry and calculus, the kind of mathematics that adolescents do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Hollywood Made 14% Fewer Shows in 2023, Marking the End of Peak TV
description: The decline is the most definitive evidence of a slowdown in new programming that has been predicted for at least a year.
content: It’s official: Peak TV has peaked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Rolling Stone’s Top Editor Steps Down
description: Noah Shachtman, the magazine’s editor in chief since 2021, is resigning because of editorial differences with the chief executive, Gus Wenner.
content: Noah Shachtman, the top editor of Rolling Stone, is stepping down at the end of the month after a stint of more than two years at the helm of the pop culture bible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Release of Hur Report Underlines Perils of the Special Counsel’s Job
description: Critics have called Robert K. Hur’s descriptions of President Biden’s memory outside his purview. Others say his narrative was probably motivated by seeking to justify not charging Mr. Biden.
content: In January 2023, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland appointed a special counsel to investigate President Biden’s handling of classified documents to avoid any perception that he was protecting his boss entering an election year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Adesina
title: ‘One Day’ Is Back. This Time, It’s Longer.
description: The hit novel became a movie, and now it’s a 14-episode Netflix series. More time let the screenwriter get deeper into the characters of Emma and Dexter.
content: For the British author David Nicholls, the key to a good romantic story is avoiding the clichés. “The first kiss, the first night together, the wedding day. There are all these landmarks which are quite familiar and quite obvious,” he said recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Is Soccer Ready to Retire Its Last Taboo?
description: A new documentary about gay players tells a story that is, in some ways, no longer a story.
content: As a teenager, Collin Martin felt he had to make a choice. For as long as he could remember, his ambition had been to become a professional soccer player, to make a living doing the thing he loved. He had a sense, though, that it was not compatible with who he was. Martin was gay, and there were — as far as he knew — no gay soccer players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Calls on U.S. to ‘Negotiate’ on Ukraine in Tucker Carlson Interview
description: In a two-hour interview, President Vladimir Putin of Russia was more direct than usual about how he sees his Ukraine invasion ending: not with a military victory, but a deal with the West.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has worked for decades to win allies in the West, using his spy agencies to interfere in elections and deploying diplomats to build links with Kremlin-friendly politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Harry Gets Damages in Hacking Case and Calls Out Piers Morgan
description: After settling his privacy claims with Mirror Group Newspapers, the prince criticized Mr. Morgan, saying the former editor of The Mirror “knew perfectly well what was going on.”
content: Prince Harry has settled his privacy claims against a British tabloid publisher, his lawyer told a London court on Friday, two months after a judge found the publisher guilty of “widespread and habitual” hacking of the prince’s cellphone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Building the Palestinian State With Salam Fayyad
description: The former prime minister of the Palestinian Authority shares his lessons on statecraft, working with Israel and what he thinks should happen now.
content: “If only we had a partner for peace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: How Does Technology Play a Role in Your Love Life? We Want to Hear From You.
description: Dating apps, smart sex toys and artificial intelligence have changed the way many of us romantically connect. We’re interested in your stories.
content: Technology has played a major role in our romantic lives since the invention of the telephone. But in the decades since, some watershed moments have shifted the terrain of dating and relationships. Pornography migrated to the internet; online dating shifted from our desktop computers to our mobile devices; social media apps made it easier to keep tabs on our exes; and our phones were equipped with the ability to sync to Bluetooth-enabled sex toys.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 9, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 9, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about the actress Da’Vine Joy Randolph who stars in “The Holdovers”  misstated the title of her breakout film. It is “Dolemite Is My Name,” not “Dolemite Is His Name.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Black Romantic Movies to Stream
description: For Valentine’s Day and Black History Month, watch these selections that brim with Black love, heartache and desire from across the diaspora.
content: Much like Blackness is not monolithic, neither is Black love. The relationships in this collection range from young passions to midlife romance, and the types of movies range from glossy studio pictures to vital queer indies. They are poetic, comedic, rapturous and politically minded films — told with soul-stirring intimacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Hills of California’ Review: A Stage Mother’s Unhappy Brood
description: Jez Butterworth’s new play explores the family dynamics of a song and dance troupe that didn’t make the big time.
content: In Jez Butterworth’s new play, we — the audience and protagonists alike — are kept waiting and wondering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Seiji Ozawa: 8 Essential Recordings
description: Ozawa, who died this week at 88 years old, left behind a catalog made with orchestras in Boston, Chicago and elsewhere. Listen to highlights.
content: Seiji Ozawa, the eminent Japanese conductor whose death, at 88, was announced on Friday, was a force at the podium. He toured the world’s leading concert halls and helped break barriers for Asian classical musicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Stein
title: This Is Not the Relationship I Ordered
description: Divorce left me with a surprising realization about who was the love of my life.
content: For years, my husband told me, “You’re the love of my life. Nothing you do could ever make me leave you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Can a New Law Force Airbnb Hosts to Become Landlords?
description: It’s too early to tell if Local Law 18 will help ease the housing crisis in New York City. But homeowners with vacant rooms aren’t eager to open them up for long-term rentals.
content: If you were planning a trip to New York City for Presidents’ Day weekend and logged onto Airbnb Wednesday morning, the first two listings to turn up might have vexed you. One was for a hotel room on Park Avenue South, and the second was for a townhouse apartment in Jersey City, advertised for its proximity to the PATH train to Manhattan, useful because Jersey City is not actually in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Fassler
title: The Revolution That Died on Its Way to Dinner
description: Cultivated meat offered a delicious fantasy: that we can consume our way out of climate catastrophe.
content: It is a gleaming vision of a world just beyond the present: a world in which meat is abundant and affordable with almost no cost to the environment. Animal slaughter is forgotten. Global warming is restrained. At the heart of the vision is a high-tech factory housing steel tanks as tall as apartment buildings and conveyor belts rolling out fully formed steaks, millions of pounds a day — enough, astonishingly, to feed an entire nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Scheeres
title: Two Memoirs of Survival and Its Long Shadow
description: “Dear Sister” and “My Side of the River” tell vastly different stories about ordinary people looking back on extraordinary circumstances.
content: After Nicole Addimando killed Chris Grover, the father of her two young children, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., in 2017, she said he’d threatened her with a gun. She’d shot him in self-defense after enduring years of physical and sexual abuse. Prosecutors claimed that Addimando killed Chris Grover while he slept and that the bruises, bite marks and burns on her body were somehow self-inflicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: True Love. Is There a Hack for That?
description: Disenchanted with dating apps, some users have taken to blaming — and gaming — the mysterious algorithms that power them.
content: If you play Call of Duty, you may be aware of an online ecosystem rich with “cheats” — shortcuts that players circulate to capitalize on the game’s glitches and thwart some of its toughest obstacles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson
title: Crowded Gazan City Bombed as Negotiators Try to Revive Cease-Fire Talks
description: A day after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu signaled that the Israeli military was preparing to move into Rafah, airstrikes there killed and wounded multiple people.
content: Israeli airstrikes hit a southern Gaza border city crowded with civilians on Thursday, a day after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denounced a cease-fire proposal by Hamas and signaled that the Israeli military was preparing to move into the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Who Will Replace George Santos? Takeaways From the Pilip-Suozzi Debate
description: Five days before a special House election in New York, Tom Suozzi and Mazi Pilip traded blows in the race’s lone debate.
content: The candidates vying to replace George Santos in a special House election squared off on Thursday in an exceedingly bitter debate, tangling over the roots of New York City’s migrant crisis, abortion rights and, at one point, the definition of “assault weapon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump’s Fever Dream of Immunity Meets Its Match
description: The man who would be king comes up against a three-judge panel.
content: On Tuesday, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit announced its decision in the case of the United States v. Trump, on the question of the former president’s immunity — or lack thereof — to federal criminal prosecution. The panel isn’t having it.
